author: George Bellshaw For Metro.Co.Uk
title: US Tennis Association apologise for singing banned version of German anthem | Metro News
text:
George Bellshaw for Metro.co.uk Saturday 11 Feb 2017 11:09 pm It was sang ahead of Petkovic’s Fed Cup match (Picture: Reuters) 
The United States Tennis Association (USTA) has issued an apology to their German Fed Cup opponents after singing the wrong version of their national anthem. 
As the USA and Germany sides met in Hawaii, disaster struck before a ball was even hit. Mesut Ozil suffering CRISIS of confidence, admits Arsenal boss Wenger 
At the ceremony ahead of the first singles clash between Andrea Petkovic and Alison Riske, the soloist sang the words to ‘Deutschland Uber Alles’ as opposed to ‘Deutschlandlied’. 
While the tune is the same, the original version has been defunct since the fall of Nazi Germany and only the third stanza of the song is used in today’s national anthem. 
The unfortunate soloist, however, belted out the words ‘Germany, Germany above all else’ rather than ‘Unity and justice and freedom for the German fatherland’. 
The first verse of the original anthem (as seen in the video above) has effectively been banned in Germany and it no doubt caused plenty of offence to those who had made the trip to Hawaii. 
The USTA was quick to apologise on Twitter for the error, writing: ‘The USTA extends a sincere apology to the German Fed Cup team & fans 4 the outdated National Anthem. The USTA extends a sincere apology to the German Fed Cup team & fans 4 the outdated National Anthem. This mistake will not occur again. pic.twitter.com/4LyG3ACe5u 
— USTA (@usta) February 11, 2017 
‘This mistake will not occur again.’ 
Germany’s own tennis federation, Deutscher Tennis Bund, quickly responded: ‘We hope so’, before the USTA assured them that the mistake would not happen again. @DTB_Tennis We can assure you that it won't. Again, our sincere apologies.
